intro: Zanthoxylum ailanthoides var. boninshimae, commonly known as the Bonin prickly ash, is a rare shrub native to the Bonin Islands. It belongs to the Rutaceae family and is characterized by its compound leaves with serrated margins. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers followed by red, fleshy berries that are an important food source for local wildlife. Its distinctive thorny stems and unique floral structure make it a notable species in its endemic habitat. Due to its limited distribution and conservation status, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists.
